page.title: 10MOUNT ST JOHN, FELIXKIRK.
page.content: Mount St John-so named because of its use as a hospital by the order of the knights of St John of Jerusalmem in the time of Henry the first. Further details to be found in 'Buildings of England' by Nikolaus Pevsner, is now the home of the Lord of the Manor. The estate covers about 1250 acres, around 600 acres are to let tenant farmers and the rest, 650 acres are farmed here with the help of a manager and 5 staff. Approximately 150 acres of this are covered with deciduous trees and the remainder is grassland. This is used for intensive sheep farming. A few pigs, sucklers and hunters are also kept. Artificial fertiliser and a small amount of herbicide is used on the land.
